fields.name: 12 Tone Equal Temperament
fields.description: The standard contemporary tuning system in Western music. Divides an octave into twelve semitones of equal size.

fields.name: 5-Limit Just Temperament
fields.description: A Just Temperament which limits the calculation of intervals to combining intervals of 2:1, 3:2, 5:4, i.e. 'just' or harmonic octaves, fifths and major thirds, respectively. This is the most commonly applied ‘just’ temperament

fields.name: Pythagorean Tuning
fields.description: Developed by Pythagoras, this tuning caculates intervals by prioritising the interval of the fifth, or 3:2.

fields.name: Arab Music (Al-Farabi)
fields.description: Al-Farabi was a prominent figure in early Arab music theory who created an influential approach to interval tuning.

fields.name: Persian Music
fields.description: The Persian musical system consists of dastgah (akin to modes, with additional properties). It has historically been associated with a 17-note scale, or sometimes quantized to 24-tone equal temperament in line with modern tempering. In reality, it’s interval material is variable by region and context.

fields.name: Indonesian Gamelan
fields.description: Gamelan music is associated with Java and Bali in Indonesia. It’s core tunings are known as Pelog and Slendro.

fields.name: Ancient Greek Music
fields.description: Ancient Greek music was tuned in one of three genera: diatonic, chromatic and enharmonic. The diatonic was akin to the contemporary diatonic; chromatic made use of of more semitones, and the enharmonic smaller intervals again, roughly equivalent to about half a semitone. As with other areas of culture, Ancient Greek music theory had a lasting and prominent effect on music theory and tuning in Europe and the Arab world. Contemporary concepts of diatonic and chromatic derive from Greek theorists.

fields.name: Indian Music
fields.description: Indian musical tuning is traditionally described in terms of 22 ‘shruti’, a subset of which is used in the pitch material of any given raga. Several alternative approaches exist to characterise a tuning which is variable by context.

fields.name: Chinese Music
fields.description: Chinese music typically makes use of a Pentatonic, harmonically tuned scale.

fields.name: Bohlen-Pierce Scale
fields.description: The Bohlen-Pierce scale was developed in the 1970s. It takes the 3:1 interval as its fundamental harmonic ratio, in place of the 2:1 octave typical of many music systems.
